newsitem.title: ISRAEL: PLO says Israel behind second Gaza blast.
newsitem.headline: PLO says Israel behind second Gaza blast.

text.p: Israel said suicide bombers aiming to kill Jews were behind twin explosions in Gaza on Tuesday, but Palestinians said Israeli troops caused one of the blasts.

The Israeli army said two bombers died in separate attacks, one of which wounded five Arabs in a taxi. Palestinians conceded one of the dead men blew himself up, but said the other was killed by a bomb or grenade thrown from an Israeli jeep.
No Israelis were hurt in the incidents.

The blasts came against a backdrop of stalled Israeli-PLO peace talks and Israeli charges Palestinian President Yasser Arafat has failed to curb militants in areas of the West Bank and Gaza under his control.
In separate incidents, Israeli forces on Tuesday shot dead two Arabs in the West Bank, where clashes over Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem flared for a 13th straight day.

In a blast near Kfar Darom settlement, a Palestinian dressed in military uniform was ripped apart by an explosion on the main Gaza-Rafah road and five taxi passengers were wounded in the Tuesday morning blast.

An aide to Palestinian President Yasser Arafat said: "In Kfar Darom area, an Israeli military jeep hurled a grenade or a bomb at (Palestinian) passersby killing one and wounding others. This is information that we have collected from passersby and victims," Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, secretary-general of the Palestinian cabinet, told Reuters.
An Israeli army spokesman rejected the Palestinian account.
"It is absolutely incorrect. There were two suicide attacks and two bombs," the spokesman said.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office quoted him as saying the blasts were proof that Arafat's "Palestinian Authority has not yet taken the necessary efforts against terror. Terror organisations still understand that they have a green light to act against Israel and its citizens".

Earlier, Palestinian police officials said that a man with five kg (11 lb) of explosives on his back blew himself up on the side of the road at 7 a.m. (0400 GMT) about two km (1.5 miles) from the Jewish settlement of Netzarim south of Gaza City.
The second blast occurred about two km (1.5 miles) from Kfar Darom near the refugee camp of Deir al-Balah.
Both settlements, heavily armed Jewish enclaves in self-ruled Gaza, have been the focus of Palestinian attacks.
The Islamist militant group Hamas denied it was behind the explosions, accusing Israel of ordering the blasts to sour relations between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority.

"This bombing was done by the Israeli intelligence and its (Palestinian) collaborators in an attempt to create an internal problem between the Islamic movement and the Palestinian Authority," Hamas official Sayed Abu Musameh told Reuters.
Last month Hamas claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv in which three Israeli women were killed.
Israeli-PLO ties have plunged to severe crisis since Israel broke ground on a new settlement in East Jerusalem last month.
Netanyahu has conditioned any further progress toward peace on a Palestinian crackdown on militants in self-ruled areas.

In the West Bank town of Nablus, undercover Palestinian policeman Haitham Mansour, 20, was shot dead by Israeli soldiers who opened fire at stone-throwing Palestinians near a checkpoint on the city's outskirts, witnesses said.

In another West Bank incident on Tuesday, a Palestinian youth was shot dead in Hebron. The Israeli army said soldiers spotted several Arabs engaging in theft. It said all but one fled in a car and that troops shot him as he fled on foot.
"The suspect did not stop and soldiers fired at him," an army spokesman said.
Both Gaza explosions occurred around 7 a.m., about the time Israeli children leave two nearby Jewish settlements on buses for school, Jewish settlers said.
"We can suppose that the operative goal at that hour was school buses or settler commuters who go to work at that hour," Israeli Southern Commander Shlomo Yanai said.
Settlers, enraged by the blasts, demanded Israeli troops invade PLO-ruled areas to uproot "terror".
After the Tuesday blast at Netzarim, settlers hurled rocks at passing Arab motorists after the blast, witnesses said.
